sen.j: 大老（たいろう）は、江戸幕府の職制で、将軍の補佐役、臨時に老中の上に置かれた最高職。
sen.e: Tairo is the highest post in the Edo bakufu government system, provisionally placed above Roju as an assistant to Shogun.
Tairo was the highest post in the Edo bakufu government system, provisionally placed above Roju as an assistant to Shogun.

sen.j: より広義には、大名家・執政機関の最高責任者群を指す（豊臣政権の五大老などがよく知られる）。
sen.e: In a broad sense, this term was used for indicating the highest responsible persons in a daimyo family or in an administrative body (Five Tairo persons in the Toyotomi government were well known).

In a broad sense, this term was used for indicating the highest responsible persons in a daimyo family or in an administrative body (Gotairo [Council of Five Elders] in the Toyotomi government were well known).

sen.j: 非常置の職で定員は通常１名。
sen.e: It was not a standing post, and the number of the members was ordinarily one.

sen.j: 重要な政策の決定にのみ関与し（大政参与）、評定所への出勤や月番などの日常業務は免除されていた。
sen.e: Tairo was involved only in important policy decisions (called Taisei-sanyo), and was exempted from doing daily jobs, such as commuting to Hyojosho (the conference chamber) and handling daily affairs in a monthly rotation.

sen.j: 初期の幕閣では松平定勝や松平忠明といった徳川家康の信頼が厚い親族（徳川家綱時代の保科正之もこれに近い）や井伊直孝・酒井忠世などの重臣（井伊・酒井両名が大老に就任したかどうかについては意見が分かれている）が元老としての役割を果たしていたが、その役割をベテランの老中に担わせた職掌とみることができる。
sen.e: In the cabinet officials of the Shogunate in the early Edo period, Tokugawa family members deeply trusted by Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, such as Sadakatsu MATSUDAIRA and Tadaakira MATSUDAIRA, (Masayuki HOSHINA in the Ietsuna TOKUGAWA era occupied the similar position), or senior vassals, such as Naotaka II and Tadayo SAKAI (there are different opinions about whether both of Ii and Sakai were appointed to the Tairo post) played the role of Genro (an elder statesman), and it is considered that this Tairo post was established for having this role assumed by the senior member of Roju.

sen.j: その意味では譜代大名の名誉職的な意味合いが強い職であったが、酒井忠清・井伊直弼のように自らに権力を集中させる者もいた。
sen.e: In that sense, Tairo was rather a honorary post for a Fudai daimyo (a daimyo who had belonged to the Tokugawa group from before the Sekigawara war), but some at the post, such as Tadakiyo SAKAI and Naosuke II, exerted overwhelming power.
